block.p: To reassure readers baffled by Bob Herbert's Sept. 7 column, ''Bush's Medicare Fix,'' I am pleased to reaffirm Congressional Republicans' strong support for Medicare and those who depend upon it.
To reassure readers baffled by Bob Herbert's Sept. 7 column, ''Bush's Medicare Fix,'' I am pleased to reaffirm Congressional Republicans' strong support for Medicare and those who depend upon it.

However, it is true that Medicare faces a dire threat. The threat is posed by those who clamor to add huge new expenses onto Medicare but rule out modernizing reforms that could place it on a sounder financial footing. Such rhetoric is particularly dangerous in light of the baby boomers' impending retirement.

The Medicare reforms that Gov. George W. Bush envisions are based on proposals that have been advanced by members of both parties. Medicare can be saved and strengthened for tomorrow's elderly, but we must first choose the path of bipartisanship and rational discussion.
The writer, an Iowa Republican, is chairman of the Senate Special Committee on Aging.
